channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Xi and Putin Bind China and Russia’s Economies Further, Despite War in Ukraine
item.description: On the second day of the Chinese leader’s state visit in Moscow, Xi Jinping and Vladimir V. Putin declared an enduring economic partnership, in an effort to insulate their countries from punitive Western measures.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins and Chris Buckley
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A photo released by Russian state media on Tuesday shows President Xi Jinping of China and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at the Grand Kremlin Palace in Moscow.

item.title: Its Forces Under Siege, Ukraine Hits Distant, Russian-Held Crimea
item.description: The Crimean Peninsula, which Russia seized in 2014, has been a staging ground for other attacks and an increasingly attractive target for Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A soldier from Ukraine’s 28th Separate Mechanized Brigade firing a grenade on Monday in the Donetsk region. Russian forces have gained ground around the Ukrainian stronghold of Avdiivka, also in Donetsk.

item.title: The Head Spinning Reality of Venezuela’s Economy
item.description: After years of extreme scarcity, some Venezuelans lead lives of luxury as others scrape by. The nation of grinding hardship has increasingly become one of haves and have-nots.
item.dc:creator: Isayen Herrera, Frances Robles and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
item.media:description: Chefs preparing a meal at Altum, a restaurant suspended on a crane over Caracas, the Venezuelan capital.

item.title: Macron Appears Ready to Tough Out France’s Pension Crisis
item.description: Amid protests in the streets and in Parliament, the French leader shows no sign of scrapping a law that raises the retirement age.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emmanuel Macron during the presidential election last year, when he promised to raise the legal retirement age in France.

item.title: Israel Votes to Scrap Law Barring Settlers at Four Evacuated West Bank Sites
item.description: In a highly symbolic action for Israel’s settler movement, lawmakers approved a first step toward resettling evacuated areas amid spiraling Israeli-Palestinian tensions.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers guard the road outside the former settlement of Homesh in 2021.

item.title: As War in Ukraine Grinds On, China Helps Refill Russian Drone Supplies
item.description: China has shipped more than $12 million in drones to Russia since it invaded Ukraine, in an indication of quiet collaboration between the two.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, Aaron Krolik and Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: A truck carrying an unmanned aerial vehicle during a military parade in Beijing in 2019.

item.title: A Massive Trump Painting Is Mysteriously Missing
item.description: A portrait of former President Donald J. Trump by a Salvadoran painter is one of several gifts to the presidential family that is now unaccounted for.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: Francisco Antonio López Benavides, a Salvadoran artist, showing part of a life-size portrait of former President Donald J. Trump that he was commissioned to paint in 2020.

item.title: Boris Johnson Admits Misleading U.K. Parliament Over Lockdown Parties
item.description: Former Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, who will testify before a committee investigating whether he lied to lawmakers, said any misinformation was not intentional.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: “When the statements were made, they were made in good faith and on the basis of what I honestly knew and believed at the time,” former Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain wrote in a statement to a parliamentary committee.

item.title: Why China and Russia Are Closer Than Ever
item.description: This week’s meeting between the leaders of China and Russia marks another key moment in the deepening relationship between the two powers.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Hong
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and China’s leader, Xi Jinping, in Beijing in February 2022. After that meeting, the leaders declared their commitment to a friendship with “no limits.”

item.title: Saudi Arabia Frees Saad Almadi, U.S. Dual Citizen Jailed for Dissent
item.description: Saad Almadi, 72, a Florida resident, was one of several Americans and hundreds of Saudis caught up in the crackdown under Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. He still cannot fly home, his son said.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Almadi family, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Saad Almadi, right, with his son, Ibrahim. Mr. Almadi, a retired project manager, was arrested during a visit to Saudi Arabia in 2021.

item.title: Report Finds London Police Force Is Sexist and Racist
item.description: The report, ordered up after the murder of Sarah Everard by a London police officer in 2021, denounced the culture within Britain’s largest police force and called for change.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Louise Casey, center, was appointed to conduct an independent review into the standards of behavior and the internal culture of the London Metropolitan Police Service.

item.title: Report of Wuhan Market Samples Found Covid and Raccoon Dog Genetic Material
item.description: In a much-anticipated study, experts described a swab that was positive for the coronavirus and contained loads of genetic material from raccoon dogs.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: Security at the entrance to the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market in Wuhan on Jan. 11, 2020.

item.title: Macron Plots Next Move in French Pensions Dispute
item.description: The future of President Emmanuel Macron’s second term was unclear after a no-confidence vote triggered by his effort to raise France’s retirement age fell short by only nine votes.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Legislators in the National Assembly in Paris on Monday protesting against the increase in the pension age.

item.title: Ukrainian Soldiers Speed Through U.S. Training on Patriot Missiles
item.description: At the end of a 10-week crash course at a U.S. Army base in Oklahoma, the Ukrainians are essentially running their own training in preparation for the front lines.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: A U.S.-made Patriot surface-to-air missile system in Zamosc, Poland, in February.

item.title: Russian Faced Prison Time for Instagram Post About War in Ukraine
item.description: The case of Olesya Krivtsova, a Russian student who ended up on the Kremlin’s official terrorist list, has underscored the perils of using social media to criticize the Kremlin’s war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Olesya Krivtsova in court in Russia. She said she later fled the country because she did not believe her chances of being exonerated were high amid a broader Kremlin crackdown on free speech.

item.title: At Al Aqsa Mosque, Shards of Stained Glass Tell a Story of Conflict
item.description: Artisans at the contested Jerusalem holy site, known to Jews as the Temple Mount, complain of Israeli interference with their work and face a constant struggle to keep up with repairs after violence flares.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Afif Amireh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Renovations in September on a window in the Qibli Mosque, one of two main structures inside the Aqsa compound.

item.title: As Haiti’s Police Retreat, Gangs Take Over Much of the Capital
item.description: Even wealthier areas in the capital, Port-au-Prince, are no longer immune to violence as gangs attack police officers and destroy police stations.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron and Andre Paultre
item.media:description: People walk past members of the Haitian National Police in March as they attempt to repel gangs in a neighborhood near the Presidential Palace in Port-au-Prince.

item.title: U.K. Inflation Swings Upward, to 10.4 Percent
item.description: Prices in Britain reversed a recent downward trend, rising by 10.4 percent in the year through February.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Sam Bush for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oxford Street shoppers in London. The Bank of England has raised rates by nearly 4 percentage points in an effort to stem high inflation.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Closer ties between Russia and China.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: During an appearance with President Xi Jinping of China, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said China’s plan could be taken as a basis for peaceful settlement in Ukraine. Kyiv’s Western allies have criticized the framework as unreasonable.

item.title: Pulling the Plug on TikTok Will Be Harder Than It Looks
item.description: The tensions over the Chinese-owned social media app will come to a head on Thursday, when the company’s chief executive testifies on Capitol Hill.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, David McCabe and Sapna Maheshwari
item.media:description: The TikTok app has 150 million users in the United States, but some fear that its Chinese parent company might give Beijing access to American users’ data.

item.title: A ‘Rocking Chair Rebellion’: Seniors Call On Banks to Dump Big Oil
item.description: Older climate activists gathered in cities around the country for a day of action targeting banks that finance fossil fuel projects.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:credit: Craig Hudson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Two protesters outside a Chase Bank in Washington, part of a demonstration organized by Third Act, a group for older climate activists, on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: China, Japan Divided on Ukraine
item.description: Also, an I.M.F. loan to Sri Lanka and the Japan-U.S. final in the World Baseball Classic.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: This photograph released by Russian state media showing Russian President Vladimir Putin and Chinese President Xi Jinping attending a reception at the Kremlin in Moscow on Tuesday.

item.title: Here Is What Putin and Xi Agreed to During Their Moscow Meeting
item.description: The two leaders did not reveal any progress toward achieving peace in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Vladimir Astapkovich/Sputnik, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin of Russia and China’s president, Xi Jinping, following their talks at the Kremlin on Tuesday.

item.title: U.S. Plans to Send Abrams Tanks to Ukraine Far Sooner Than Expected
item.description: Excess M1A1 tank “hulls” are to be refitted and refurbished to make them ready on a quicker timeline for Ukraine than new tanks could be delivered.
item.dc:creator: John Ismay
item.media:description: M1A1 Abrams battle tanks during an exercise in Latvia in 2021.

item.title: Justice Dept. Embraces Supporting Role in Pursuing War Crimes in Ukraine
item.description: Prosecutors are investigating war crimes against Americans but are mainly focused on helping Ukraine to hold Russians accountable for atrocities.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland, center, has said that U.S. prosecutors had identified “several specific” Russians suspected of war crimes against Americans.

item.title: A Translation Problem
item.description: A small change to climate science could make a big difference for Americans.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Roger Kisby for The New York Times
item.media:description: A thermometer reading greeting visitors at Death Valley National Park in California in 2021.

item.title: Notes From One Woman’s Decade of Eating Scones
item.description: A Londoner spent 10 years sampling scones at hundreds of historic sites across the U.K. Here’s why her story made headlines — and which essential topping she says should come before the other.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: The National Trust Book of Scones (Book)

item.title: Following a Folk Tale Through the Himalayas
item.description: On a trip through northern India, a writer was guided by the age-old epic story of “Rajula Malushahi,” which led him to a series of unexpected places.
item.dc:creator: Michael Benanav
item.media:description: The Panchachuli peaks, a group of five snow-capped Himalayan peaks that reach 22,651 feet, and Rajramba, which reaches 21,447 feet, on the left, tower over the Johar Valley in Kumaon.

item.title: Japan’s Prime Minister Fumio Kishida Visits Ukraine
item.description: Fumio Kishida, who has been seeking a more active role for his country in international affairs, made an unannounced trip to meet with Ukraine’s president.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Victoria Kim
item.media:description: Prime Minister Fumio Kishida of Japan made an unannounced visit to Ukraine on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Xi Jinping’s visit to Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Russian Presidential Press Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Xi Jinping and Vladimir Putin met Monday at the Kremlin.

item.title: Ukraine Says Explosion in Crimea Destroyed Russian Cruise Missiles
item.description: Kremlin-appointed authorities in Crimea denied the claim saying that all the drones had been “aimed at civilian objects.”
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: A damaged Kalibr missile used by the Russian Army in the Kharkiv region of northeastern Ukraine in October.

item.title: Putin and Xi Celebrate Ties Unbroken by Russia’s War in Ukraine
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin welcomed Xi Jinping, China’s top leader, to Russia, briefly noting Beijing’s peace plan for Ukraine but stressing Moscow and Beijing’s enduring partnership.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins, Chris Buckley and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Grigory Sysoyev/Sputnik, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Macron’s Government Survives No-Confidence Vote Amid France’s Wrath Over Pensions
item.description: Two no-confidence votes failed to oust the cabinet of President Emmanuel Macron over a new law raising the retirement age to 64 from 62.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: The French National Assembly debated two no-confidence votes against President Emmanuel Macron’s government on Monday. Mr. Macron’s government survived both votes.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Xi Meets Putin in Moscow
item.description: Also, a major U.N. climate report and a manhunt in the Indian state of Punjab.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: This photograph released by Russian state media showing Russian President Vladimir Putin and Chinese President Xi Jinping at a meeting at the Kremlin in Moscow on Monday.

item.title: Xi Condemns Killings in African Nation Where Russian and Chinese Interests Compete
item.description: Nine Chinese nationals were killed in the Central African Republic, where the Kremlin-aligned Wagner group controls a gold mine and Chinese companies have built their own operations.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue of Russian soldiers at the corner in central Bangui, Central African Republic, in November.

item.title: Biden Administration Authorizes $350 Million for Ukraine Military Aid
item.description: The latest infusion of aid is aimed at giving Ukraine much needed ammunition ahead of a planned spring offensive.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:credit: Jam Sta Rosa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: U.S. Marines working on a High Mobility Artillery Rocket Systems or HIMARS, in Capas, Philippines, in October.

item.title: Blinken Says Xi’s Russia Visit Amounts to ‘Diplomatic Cover’ for War Crimes
item.description: The U.S. secretary of state said the Chinese leader’s visit indicated that Beijing felt “no responsibility” to hold Russia accountable for atrocities in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken addressing reporters in Washington on Monday.

item.title: Who’s Behind the Judicial Overhaul Now Dividing Israel? Two Americans.
item.description: Kohelet, the once-obscure think tank that conceived and now champions a revamped court system, is an American import.
item.dc:creator: David Segal and Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Tens of thousands of Israelis protested the government’s judicial overhaul plan on March 11.

item.title: Meta Manager Was Hacked With Spyware and Wiretapped in Greece
item.description: Artemis Seaford, a dual U.S.-Greek national, was targeted with a cyberespionage tool while also under a wiretap by the Greek spy agency in a case that shows the spread of illicit snooping in Europe.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.media:description: Artemis Seaford, shown in Washington this year, worked as a trust and safety manager for Meta from 2020 until late 2022.

item.title: European Officials Agree to Supply More Artillery Shells to Ukraine
item.description: European leaders adopted a plan to provide Ukraine with badly needed shells, while replenishing their own national stocks.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian armed forces loading a howitzer in the Donetsk region in May.

item.title: First Official Estimate of Somalia’s Drought Shows 43,000 Dead
item.description: At least half of the deaths were children under the age of 5, according to the report by health researchers, the United Nations and the Somali government.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Andrea Bruce for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lining up at a nutrition center run by a charitable group in Baidoa, Somalia, in November.

item.title: Israel’s Leaders Advance Key Part of Judicial Overhaul but Delay Rest
item.description: The government vowed to press on with a plan to take more control over appointing judges. But other changes were postponed in a move that was presented as a concession.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: A rally protesting the judicial overhaul blocked a highway in Tel Aviv on Saturday. The debate over the proposals has set off one of the deepest domestic crises in Israeli history.

item.title: What to Expect From France’s No-Confidence Vote
item.description: Lawmakers in the National Assembly will debate two motions to oust President Emmanuel Macron’s cabinet and defeat his plan to raise the national retirement age.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: The French government has exposed itself to no-confidence motions that could bring down President Emmanuel Macron’s cabinet.

item.title: French government and Macron’s retirement overhaul survive a no-confidence vote. Here’s the latest.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden

item.title: American Held Hostage in Africa Is Freed
item.description: Jeffery Woodke, an aid worker abducted in Niger by militants, was released after more than six years in captivity. A second hostage was also released: Olivier Dubois, a French journalist who disappeared in April 2021.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Adam Goldman
item.media:description: Jeffery Woodke, an American, was kidnapped in Niger in October 2016.

item.title: 1948: Egypt Starts Power Project
item.description: Laying the foundation stone of a hydroelectric project that would have ambitious successors.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: Australian State Moves to Ban Nazi Salute After Rally
item.description: After neo-Nazis appeared at a protest against transgender rights in Melbourne, a local politician was facing expulsion from her party for taking part in the demonstration.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Members of an Australian neo-Nazi group during a rally against transgender rights at Parliament House in Melbourne on Saturday.

item.title: Who Are Russia’s Friends Amid the War in Ukraine?
item.description: India and South Africa are among the nations that have not criticized Russia for invading Ukraine. Some others have supplied military aid.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, right, and President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko of Belarus in Minsk, Belarus, in December.

item.title: Earth to Hit Critical Global Warming Threshold by Early 2030s
item.description: A new report says it is still possible to hold global warming to relatively safe levels, but doing so will require global cooperation, billions of dollars and big changes.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.media:description: Hoesung Lee, chair of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, speaking at the global climate talks on Nov. 6 in Sharm el Sheikh, Egypt.

item.title: India Blocks Internet in Punjab as Security Forces Pursue Separatist
item.description: The rise of Amritpal Singh, a self-styled preacher, has raised fears of violence in Punjab, where thousands died in the 1980s during a Sikh insurgency.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir and Suhasini Raj
item.media:description: Police officers outside the home of Amritpal Singh in Jallupur Khera, a village about 30 miles from Amritsar, India.

item.title: What Could Happen If Trump Is Indicted This Week
item.description: If Trump is indicted, this week will be unlike any other in American politics.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:description: Donald Trump.

item.title: A WWII Pilot Saved His Crew. It Took 80 Years to Identify His Remains.
item.description: Lt. William B. Montgomery flew a B-24 Liberator toward the British coast after it was hit in June 1944. Historians credit him for saving the lives of seven crew members.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:description: First Lt. William B. Montgomery, front row, second from right, with other members of the U.S. Army Air Forces. He piloted a B-24 Liberator that was struck by antiaircraft fire while on a mission to bomb an airfield near the German-occupied Paris.

item.title: Lead Exposure From U.S. Car Batteries Threatens Health of Mexican Workers
item.description: The removal of lead from car batteries, many from the United States, at recycling plants in northern Mexico has led to high levels of lead contamination, a new report found.
item.dc:creator: Steve Fisher and Alejandro Cegarra
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: After tests showed high levels of lead in Azael Mateo González Ramírez’s body, his supervisor at a car battery recycling plant in northern Mexico insisted he keep working.

item.title: Some Details on the Agenda for Xi Jinping’s Visit to Russia
item.description: The Chinese leader is expected to talk to Vladimir V. Putin about Ukraine and other issues.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Cassandra Vinograd
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Moscow in 2019.

item.title: The Children of the Iraq War Have Grown Up, but Some Wounds Don’t Heal
item.description: Twenty years after the U.S. invaded Iraq, a veteran Times correspondent and photographer asked Iraqis about growing up in wartime, and about their hopes now.
item.dc:creator: Joao Silva and Alissa J. Rubin

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Will Trump be arrested this week?
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Donald Trump speaking last week in Iowa.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: Putin and Xi to Meet in Moscow
item.description: Also, Donald Trump says his arrest is imminent and UBS agrees to buy Credit Suisse.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: An image taken from video footage released on Sunday by Russian TV shows President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Mariupol, Ukraine.

item.title: Lab Leak or Not? How Politics Shaped the Battle Over Covid’s Origin
item.description: A lab leak was once dismissed by many as a conspiracy theory. But the idea is gaining traction, even as evidence builds that the virus emerged from a market.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: The Wuhan Institute of Virology is known for its advanced research on bat coronaviruses.
